title: Particle motion from v(t_=1-arctan(e^t) part - c

content.description: A particle moves along the y-axis so that its velocity v at time <math> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </math> is given by <math> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> <mo>−</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>tan</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mi>t</mi> </msup> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </math>. At time <math> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </math>, the particle is at <math> <mrow> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mo>-</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </math>. (Note:  <math> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>tan</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>arctan</mi> <mtext> </mtext> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </math>)
content.question: Find the time <math> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </math> at which the particle reaches its highest point. Justify your answer.

frqParts.text: Find the time <math> <mrow> <mi>t</mi> <mo>≥</mo> <mn>0</mn> </mrow> </math> at which the particle reaches its highest point. Justify your answer.

topic.text: 5.4: Using the First Derivative Test to Determine Relative (Local) Extrema
